Au*, H. He, S.Y. Lai, C.F. Ng Department of Chemistry. and Centre for Surface Analysis and Research. Hong Kong Baptist University, Kowloon Tong, Hong Kong Received 13 September 1996; received in revised form 17 December 1996; accepted 19 December 1996 Abstract The performance of LaOC1 at 800 was promoted by BaCO3 in OCM reaction. When 10 mol% BaCO3 was added, there was little change in CH4 conversion, but C2 selectivity was increased from 37% to 66%. With the increase in BaCO3 loading, the BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts decreased in specific surface area. The improvement in C2 selectivity is partly due to surface area diminution. The addition of BaCO3 has also caused surface modification of LaOC1. In the absence of BaCO3, LaOC1 in OCM reaction is capable of generating dioxygen species O2-, O~- and 02, which can cause deep oxidation of CH4, C2H6 and C2H4. With the addition of BaCO3, sites for the activation of oxygen molecules are depleted. The nearby C1- ions have the ability of destabilizing the BaCO3, causing it to decompose at ca. 780, a decomposition temperature about 200 lower than that of pure BaCO3. With the deprivation of dioxygen species, the CH4 oxidative dehydrogenation process is enhanced, while deep oxidation processes are suppressed. Compared with the deep oxidation reaction processes, the number of sites required in the H-abstraction process is a lot fewer. Hence, although the specific surface area of LaOC1 was reduced with the addition of BaCO3, the conversion of CH4 over the BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts did not drop significantly. Keywords: OCM reaction; BaCO3/LaOCI catalysts; CH4 activation I. Introduction In the past 15 years, research on the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) to C2 hydrocarbons has shown that alkali, alkaline earth, rare earth, and transition metal oxides are catalytically active materials. It has been demonstrated that ethylene selectivity can be promoted by chlorine, which was either added directly to the * Corresponding author. [4] reported that the LiC1/NiO catalyst performed well; with 26% methane conversion and 72% Ce selectivity, the C2 yield at 750 was 18.7%. Burch et al. [5,6] carried out a series of studies on the effect of chlorine over various catalysts. They found that pulse injection of gaseous chlorinated compounds over MnO2-based catalysts, lithium-doped MgO, and Sm203 catalysts markedly increased the C2 selectivity. They also investigated OCM reactions over Sm203, SmOC1, and SmC13 and claimed that the chlorine-containing catalysts were especially effective in ethylene production. Moffat and coworkers [7,8] investigated OCM reactions over La203, Pr6Ol~, and Sm203. They found that the addition of small amounts of tetrachloromethane to the reactant stream could improve the catalytic activity of these catalysts; they attributed the improvement to oxychloride formation. Khan and Ruckenstein [9] found that the BiOC1/LiaCO3/ MgO catalysts were active and selective. Neither BiOC1 nor LiaCO3/MgO was very effective, but BiOC1/LieCO3/MgO gave 18% CH4 conversion and 83% C2 selectivity. Lunsford et al. [10] reported that, at a temperature as low as 625, a CH4 conversion of 29% and a C2 selectivity of 60% could be obtained over Li+- MgO-C1- catalysts. As far as the function of chlorine is concerned, Burch et al. [5] claimed that, with the MgO and Sm203 catalysts, chlorine can modify the surfaces through the formation of new O- sites. Such sites may be capable of activating the weaker C-H bond in ethane more effectively than the stronger C-H bond in methane. Previously, Williams et al. [ 11 ] compared the activities of BiOC1, LaOC1, and SmOC1 and reported that LaOC1 and BiOC1 were good catalysts for OCM reaction. We have reported previously the activities of LaOF [ 12], B aF2/La203 and BaBr2/La203 [13], as well as BaCO3/LaOBr [14] catalysts for the OCM reaction. In this paper, the performance and characterization of BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts are reported. 2. Experimental The chemicals (purity 99.9%) used in the preparation of the catalysts were products of Johnson Matthey. LaOC1 was prepared by heating a ground mixture of LazO3 and LaC13 in 1 : 1 molar ratio in air in a furnace at 800 for 6 h. The BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts were prepared by mixing LaOC1 powder with the right proportion of BaCO3 in the form of aqueous suspension. After water evaporation, the mixture was ground and dried overnight in an oven at 110 and pressed into small pellets before being calcined at 800 for 6 h. The pellets were crushed and sieved to a grain size of 40-60 mesh. The 02 (99.7%), CH4 (99.9%), C2H6 (99.0%), and N2 (99.99%) gases were from Hong Kong Oxygen and were used without further purification. Catalytic interactions were studied using a laboratory-scale fixed-bed reactor system operating under atmospheric pressure. The reactor was constructed of fused C.T. Au et al./Applied Catah, sis A: General 159 (1997) 133-145 135 quartz. A thermocouple was placed in direct contact with the catalyst for accurate temperature measurement. Catalyst (0.5 g) was placed in the reactor and treated with a mixture of 02 and N2 (flow rate=50 ml min-1) at 750 for 2 h before reaction. The reactant (CH4 : 02 : N2=2.6 : 1.0 : 12) feed rate was 50 ml min 1. Products were analyzed, usually 60 rain after temperature stabilization, by an on- line gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-8A). A Porapak Q column was used to separate CH4, CO2, C2H4, and C2H6. A 5A molecular sieve column was used (in parallel) to separate N2, 02, CH4, and CO. The specific surface area of the catalysts was measured by the BET method. The continuous flow chromatographic technique was adopted, with helium as the carrier gas and nitrogen as the adsorbate. Phase composition of catalysts was determined by X-ray diffraction (D-MAX, Rigaku), whereas X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (Leybold Heraeus-Shenyang SKL-12) was used to characterize the catalyst surface. In situ Raman experiments were performed in Xiamen University, China, using a Raman spectrometer (SPEX Ramalog-6). The LaOCI and 10 mol% BaCO3/LaOCI catalysts were treated in He (1 h) and then in O2 (15 min) at 650 before the Raman experiments. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 was used to gauge the surface basicity of the catalysts. The catalyst (about 0.2 g) was packed and secured by quartz wool in a quartz reactor (i.d. 4 mm). It was pretreated by a flow of dry He (30ml min-1) at 800 for 1 h to remove adsorbates. Then the catalyst was exposed to CO2 at 800 for 0.5 h and cooled to room temperature in CO2. With the samples being heated at a rate of 13 rain- 1, the TPD spectrum was recorded within a temperature range of 30-850. The desorbed gas was carried by a flow of He to a GC-MS (HP G1800A GCD) system for monitoring. 3. Results 3.1. Catalytic performance Fig. 1 shows the performance of BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts at 800 as related to the loading of BaCO3. Over LaOC1, CH4 conversion, C2 selectivity, and C2 yield were ca. 36.9%, 29.2%, and 10.0%, respectively. When 10 mol% BaCO3 was added, there was little change in CH4 conversion, but C2 selectivity was increased by ca. 76%, resulting in an increase in C2 yield of ca. 66%. When the amount of BaCO3 added was between 10 and 30 mol%, C2 selectivity increased further. At 50 mol% BaCO3 loading, CH4 conversion was ca. 40% and with a C2 selectivity of ca. 55%, a C2 yield of approximately 22% was obtained. The specific surface areas of the BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts after OCM reaction are shown in Fig. 2. LaOC1 had a surface area of ca. 11.7 m2 g-1. At 10 and 30 mol% B aCO3 loadings, the area was ca. 9.0 m2 g- 1. Above 30 mol%, the surface area of the catalysts decreased gradually and was ca. 2.0 m2 g-1 at 70 mol% BaCO3 loading. 136 C.T. XRD and XPS studies The phase composition of the BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts was investigated by XRD. There were hexagonal La203 and La(OH)3 within the range of 0 to 100 mol%. After the OCM reaction (Fig. 3(b)), a new crystal phase, namely orthorhombic BaC12, was observed for the 30 to 70 mol% BaCO3/ LaOC1 catalysts. When compared with the catalysts before the OCM reaction, there was enhancement in the amounts of La203 and La(OH)3. At or below 20 mol% BaCO3 loading, no crystal phase of a barium compound was detected. The LaOC1 and 10 mol% BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts were chosen to be investigated by XPS. Discussion BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts have reasonable activity for OCM reactions. From 10 to 50 mol% BaCO3, C2 yield was ca. 19%. From Fig. 1, one can see that with the increase in BaCO3 loading, COx selectivity decreased. Such decrease in COx selectivity was reflected by the increase in CE selectivity. According to a hetero- geneous-homogeneous reaction scheme (Scheme 1), for example, the one that was referred to by Lin et al. [19], Iwamatsu et al. [20] and ourselves [12]. C.T. The diminution in specific surface area will make the heterogeneous steps un- favourable and relatively speaking, will enhance the homogeneous formation of C2H6. Hence, as the specific surface area of the BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts gets smaller (Fig. 2), we see a reduction in COx selectivity (steps 1, 3 and 6 retarded) and an increase in C2 selectivity (step 4 enhanced while steps 3 and 6 retarded). However, we do not see much decline in CH4 conversion. With the reduction in specific surface area, one would expect the diminution in CH4 conversion, since both steps 1 and 2 are heterogeneous in nature. As shown in Fig. 3, the crystal phase of BaCO3 was detected by XRD above 10 mol% BaCO3 loading. After the OCM reaction, another phase, viz. BaC12, was also detected. Hence one can conclude that the decrease in specific surface area of the BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts above 20 mol% BaCO3 loading is due to the existence of bulk BaCO3 and BaCI2 compounds. Au et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 133-145 143 Let us first turn our attention to the 10 mol% BaCO3/LaOC1 catalyst. When LaOC1 was promoted by 10 mol% BaCO3, the change in CH4 conversion was relatively small, but C2 selectivity was improved by ca. 76%. Based on the XPS results, one can be sure of the existence of barium compound(s) on the surface of LaOC1. Compared with the Raman signals of oxygen species O2-, O~- and 02 on LaOC1, the intensities of these species on 10 mol% BaCO3/LaOC1 were much weaker (Figs. 4 and 5). A pure BaCO3 sample could give a CO2- symmetric stretching vibration peak at ca. 1058 cm-1 [13]. As shown in Fig. 5, we did not detect any Raman signal attributable to surface carbonate, so we conclude that after various sample treatments, most of the BaCO3 added had been converted to BaO which was well-dispersed on the catalyst surface, as we did not see any crystal phase of BaO by XRD. Anyhow, the presence of BaO apparently had caused the amounts of O~-, O~- and 02 on LaOC1 to reduce. Under OCM reaction atmo- sphere at 650, no dioxygen species were detected on 10 mol% BaCO3/LaOC1 (Fig. 5(c)), while weak Raman signals of 02- and O~- could still be detected on LaOC1 (Fig. 4(c)). In contrast to the XPS results, the Raman investigations showed no detectable surface carbonate on the BaCO3-promoted catalyst in the OCM reaction, implying that the deep oxidation of CH4 to CO2 at 650 over the catalyst was not significant. Based on the XPS results, the surfaces of the LaOCI and 10 mol% BaCO3/ LaOC1 catalysts were fairly stable and remained intact after a reaction time of ca. 10 h at 800 (Table 1). One can also see that there were two types of chlorine species on the surface of the two catalysts. The decomposition temperature of pure BaCO3 is known to be ca. 990 [21]. For an untreated 10 mol% BaCO3/LaOCI catalyst, surface BaCO3 was found to decompose at ca. 790 (Fig. 7). We propose that, due to the influence of C1- ions, the decomposition temperature of BaCO3 loaded on LaOC1 was lowered to the 750-800 range (Fig. 6). We had previously suggested that bromide ions could lower the decomposition temperature of La202CO3 due to the delocalization of Br- electron into the 7r* orbital of the carbonate O-C bond [13]. A similar effect could well have affected the BaCO3 compounds on LaOC1. As the loading of BaCO3 was above 10 mol%, the decomposition temperature of surface BaCO3 rose, and above 20 mol%, CO2 desorption continued above 850 (Fig. 6(e) and (f)). As revealed by XRD investigation (Fig. 3), above 20 tool% BaCO3 loading, bulk BaCO3 was present and, relatively speaking, the influence of surface C1- on BaCO3 lessened. That is why the CO2 desorption (from BaCO3 decomposition) temperature rose with the increase of BaCO3 loading. LaOC1 was prepared by heating a mixture of La203 and LaC13 according to the chemical equation La203 + LaCI3 ---+ 3LaOC1 It is possible that, within the LaOC1 lattice, there are lattice points with either 02- or C1- missing. For these anionic vacancies, trapped electrons 144 C.T. Au et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 159 (1997) 133-145 will be present and the interaction of oxygen with such defects would generate O2-, O~- and O- species. The detection of Raman peaks corresponding to these oxygen species over LaOCI supports such a suggestion (Fig. 4). That trapped electrons can combine with molecular oxygen to form partially reduced oxygen species has been suggested by Ito et al. [22] and Wang et al. [23]. A good example is the observation of Steinberg [24], who reported the EPR signals of trapped electrons over partially reduced CeO2/SiO2 and their combination with molecular oxygen to form O~-. We suggest that, in the case of 10 mol% BaCO3/LaOC1, the presence of well-dispersed barium compounds has blocked up defect sites which originally existed on LaOC1, hindering the generation of 02-, O~- and 02 species on the catalyst. During OCM reactions, the catalysts were under a mixture of CH4 and 02 and the amount of dioxygen species on the BaCO3-promoted LaOC1 catalysts should be much less than that on LaOC1. Based on the performance of the 10 mol% BaCO3/LaOC1 catalyst (Fig. 1) and the results of Raman studies, we conclude that the suppression of surface dioxygen species has reduced the chance of deep oxidation. In our experimental conditions, 02 conversions were near 100%. Hence if methane deep oxidation was more favorable over LaOC1, the [02 conversion]/[CH4 conversion] ratio should be high; whereas with the addition of barium, methane oxidative dehydrogenation to give C2 compounds were enhanced, and the [02 conversion]/[CH4 conversion] ratio should be low. As one can see in Figs. 1 and 2, the effect of specific surface area is seen in a reduction of CH4 conversion on the samples (50-70% Ba), where the specific surface area decreases drastically. In comparison with the process for oxidative dehydrogenation of CH4, the multi-step deep oxidation of CH4 to COx and H20 required numerous sites. Hence, although the specific surface area of the BaCO3/LaOC1 catalysts was smaller than that of LaOC1, there was little change in CH4 conversion, since the surface sites were more dedicated to the dehydrogenation processes. 5. Conclusion The catalytic performance of LaOC1 was greatly enhanced by the addition of BaCO3. Methane conversion, C2 selectivity, and C2 yield of ca. 40%, 56% and 22% were obtained over the 50 mol% BaCO3/LaC1 catalyst at 800. Influenced by C1- ions nearby, surface BaCO3 decomposed at OCM reaction temperatures. It is suggested that the loading of BaCO3 on LaOC1 has suppressed the generation of dioxygen species O2-, 02- and 02 involved in deep oxidation processes. Hence, although there was a decrease in specific surface area with the addition of BaCO3 to LaOC1, the conversion of methane did not decline sig- nificantly as the multi-step deep oxidation processes in the OCM reaction were suppressed and the surface sites were more dedicated to the dehydrogenation processes of methane.
